newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Luxembourg has no plans to fix EMU currency rates.
newsitem.headline: Luxembourg has no plans to fix EMU currency rates.

text.p: Luxembourg Treasury Director Yves Mersch said on Wednesday that Luxembourg had no plans during its six-month European Union presidency to fix conversion rates for currencies joining economic and monetary union (EMU).

"We do not have a plan to fix indicative (single currency) rates," Mersch told a European Parliament monetary subcommittee. "There is a difference between a discussion of how to fix indicative rates and actually fixing them."

There has been considerable speculation in recent weeks that a method would be found during the Luxembourg presidency for fixing exchange rates to the euro, which is due to be launched on January 1, 1999.
Many EU policymakers are worried about the potential market turbulence that could result from the prolonged uncertainty over how currency rates would be fixed.
Mersch said it was clear a way had to be found to avoid a situation in which financial markets were unsure how exchange rates would be locked against the new single currency.
But over the next six months, he said, the Luxembourg presidency had no specific mandate to actually devise a plan to fix the rates.
"There will probably be some informal discussions, but no formal procedures," Mersch said.
One of the more popular methods advanced for locking currency rates has been adoption of the central parity rates within the current European Exchange Rate Mechanism.

Since most currencies in the grid are presently trading close to their central parities, officials say a decision to use the parities as the conversion rates for EMU would alleviate undesired market speculation.

Under the Maastricht Treaty the EU is constrained in deciding in advance what the conversion rates would be against the euro, a decision that will have to wait until December 31, 1998, one day prior to the single currency's launch.
But some pre-announced method for conversion is widely seen as a necessary step and would perhaps be unveiled when the participating countries are chosen in the spring of 1998.
"We are conscious of the fact that you cannot have everything building up to a certain date and then have a very long night," Mersch said.
